abstract: At the request of lender Bank of America, a judge named a receiver for a Chicago mall that has been two decades in development, wresting control from the project’s developer Joseph Freed & Associates.
snippet: At the request of lender Bank of America, a judge named a receiver for a Chicago mall that has been two decades in development, wresting control from the project’s developer Joseph Freed & Associates.
lead_paragraph: It took nearly two decades to get to this day, but on Nov. 20, Block 37, a five-level mall in the heart of this Chicago’s downtown, got the green light to open its public areas. However, the developer, Joseph Freed & Associates, was not celebrating, The New York Times’s Terry Pristin writes.

headline.main: Bank’s Action Rattles a New Mall in Chicago

abstract: Bank of America said late Wednesday that it would repay the entire $45 billion in bailout money that it received from the government. It said the money would be repaid after it completed a securities offering.
snippet: Bank of America said late Wednesday that it would repay the entire $45 billion in bailout money that it received from the government. It said the money would be repaid after it completed a securities offering.
lead_paragraph: Update | 10:23 p.m. Louise Story of The New York Times provides more details of Bank of America’s decision to repay $45 billion in federal aid.

headline.main: Bank of America to Repay $45 Billion From TARP
